choices.text: Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that breech presentation identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery is false.

 

Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is not automatically a contraindication for a vaginal breech delivery. It is crucial to assess the situation carefully, considering the skill of the obstetrician and the facilities available, but it does not universally rule out the possibility of a vaginal breech delivery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available: This is correct because the presence of a facility for emergency cesarean section is essential for managing unexpected complications during a breech delivery.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor: This is correct because continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial to detect any signs of fetal distress during a breech delivery.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: This is correct as vaginal breech deliveries should be performed by an experienced and skilled obstetrician to manage the potential risks and complications effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breech presentation identified for the first-time during delivery is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery, provided other criteria are met and facilities are available.

 

Ref: Page no 449, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below? (INICET MAY 2018)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women not on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿It is removed once the patient starts ambulating.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows a pneumatic compression hose. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  • It is also used along with pharmacotherapy in women at risk of thromboembolism undergoing a cesarean section
  • It is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.
  • It is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Different guidelines are there for different societies (Both ACOG and SMFM) recommend pneumatic compression devices for all patients undergoing cesarean section. This table is from Williams and shows the different guidelines:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatic compression devices are used for thromboembolism prevention in women undergoing cesarean sections, whether or not they are on thromboprophylaxis, and are discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.

 

Ref: Page 2575, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is less then 1 cm dilated and length is 3 cm. The vertex is at -2 station and the cervix is soft and anterior. What will be the bishop score for this lady? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5

 

Explanation:

 

The Bishop's score, in this case, is 5.

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor.
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor.
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm).
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:

 

 

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bishop score is used to evaluate the readiness of the cervix for induction of labor. A score of 6 or more suggests that the cervix is favorable for induction.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria engulfed by macrophages
﻿﻿﻿Neutrophil engulfed bacteria
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria arranged in clusters

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

 

The microscopic finding described is consistent with "clue cells," which are a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis (BV). Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are covered with a stippled appearance due to bacteria adhering to their surface. This attachment creates a poorly defined border on the cell. Clue cells are significant in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis because they are a reliable indicator of this condition. For a diagnosis of BV, at least 20 percent of epithelial cells in a wet mount preparation should appear as clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding is more indicative of an inflammatory response and is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly associated with other types of infections or inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: This description is associated with acute bacterial infections or inflammation but not with bacterial vaginosis, where clue cells are the key finding.

 

Option D. Bacteria arranged in clusters: While bacteria may be present in clusters in some infections, this description does not specifically identify the clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells, which are epithelial cells with bacteria attached on their surface, are the most reliable microscopic indicator of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 3 swab test

questions.text: What is the most useful test in vesicovaginal fistula? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula (VVF). It allows direct visualization of the bladder and can help identify the exact location, size, and number of fistulas. Additionally, cystoscopy can be used to assess the bladder for any associated injuries or other abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. 3 swab test: This test is used to identify the type of genitourinary fistula (vesicovaginal or ureterovaginal) but is not as specific as cystoscopy for visualizing the fistula directly.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic structures and help in the diagnosis of fistulas, it is not the first-line investigation. It is more useful in complex cases or when additional information is needed.

 

Option D. Cystometry: This test evaluates bladder filling and voiding problems and is not specific for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for directly visualizing vesicovaginal fistulas, determining their size, location, and number, and assessing the bladder for any associated injuries.

 

Ref: Page no 417, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Colposcopy with LEEP

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy with LEEP

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III (CIN 3) is a severe form of cervical dysplasia that is diagnosed by cervical biopsy. The standard treatment for CIN 2 or CIN 3 is an excisional procedure, which aims to remove the affected tissue to prevent progression to invasive cancer.

 

  • LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure):
    • LEEP is the excisional procedure of choice for treating CIN 3.
    • It involves using a thin wire loop that is heated by electric current to excise the transformation zone of the cervix where abnormal cells are located.
    • LEEP is also known as LLETZ (Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It is generally not the first-line treatment for CIN 3 unless there are other indications, such as concurrent invasive cancer or other gynecological conditions.

 

Option B. Trachelectomy: This procedure involves removing the cervix while preserving the uterus. It is more commonly used for early-stage cervical cancer in women who wish to preserve fertility.

 

Option C. Conization: While conization (removal of a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix) is a valid treatment for CIN 3, LEEP is often preferred due to its effectiveness and lower morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CIN 3 is best treated with an excisional procedure, with the Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP) being the procedure of choice.

 

Ref: Page no 328, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

questions.text: Pregnant women with which of the following is called systemic hypertension? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is classified as chronic hypertension if it is diagnosed in the first trimester or if hypertension persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum. Hypertension present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation also qualifies as chronic hypertension. This is distinct from gestational hypertension, which develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman.

 

  • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: This condition is a complication of diabetes affecting the eyes, not a direct indicator of systemic hypertension.

 

Option C. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a complication of diabetes that affects the kidneys and can be associated with hypertension, but it is not specific to the definition of systemic hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Episode of seizure: Seizures in the context of pregnancy are associated with eclampsia, a severe form of preeclampsia, but do not directly define systemic hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is diagnosed if high blood pressure is present before pregnancy, is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of PCOD except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulipristal

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of PCOD.
    • It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator.
    • It is used as an emergency contraceptive and in medical management of fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene: Clomiphene is an anti-estrogen used in ovulation induction in women with PCOS (1st line agent) and infertility

 

  • Gonadotropins can also be used in PCOS with infertility in those who have clomiphene resistance (2nd line therapy)

 

Option B. Letrozole: But nowadays Letrozole (aromatase inhibitor) is the drug for ovulation induction in PCOS with infertility.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: It is recommended as second-line therapy in PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator primarily used for emergency contraception and managing uterine fibroids.

 

Ref: Page 244, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Contraction stress test

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

 

The fetal biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive assessment used to evaluate fetal well-being, and it includes five components:

 

  1. NST (Non-Stress Test): Evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): Assessed through ultrasound to check the amount of amniotic fluid.
  3. Fetal Movement: Observes fetal movements through ultrasound.
  4. Fetal Tone: Evaluates the presence of fetal muscle tone and limb movements.
  5. Fetal Breathing: Assesses the presence and duration of fetal breathing movements.

 

The Contraction Stress Test (CST) is not part of the BPP. Instead, it is a separate test used to assess the fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, helping to evaluate how well the fetus handles the stress of contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal movement: This is a component of the BPP, assessing the number of fetal movements.

 

Option B. Fetal breathing: This is a component of the BPP, evaluating the presence of fetal breathing movements.

 

Option C. NST: The Non-Stress Test is a key component of the BPP, measuring fetal heart rate reactivity to movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.

 

Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following hormones will be secreted in high amounts by the ovarian granulosa cells during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estrogen

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, the granulosa cells of the developing follicles secrete high amounts of estrogen, specifically estradiol. This phase is characterized by the development of a primordial follicle to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles. The following events occur during this phase:

 

  • Estrogen Secretion: Granulosa cells secrete increasing amounts of estrogen, primarily estradiol, which causes proliferation of the endometrium in preparation for potential implantation.
  • Up-regulation of Receptors: LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in both theca and granulosa cells.
  • Feedback Mechanism: The rising estradiol levels exert a negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary, suppressing the secretion of FSH and LH to moderate levels.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): FSH is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles but is not secreted by granulosa cells.

 

Option C. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH is also secreted by the anterior pituitary and plays a role in the later stages of follicle development and ovulation.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum after ovulation during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, ovarian granulosa cells secrete high amounts of estrogen, which is crucial for the proliferation of the endometrium and regulation of FSH and LH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 78, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period
Beta HCG estimation
Serum FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient has been on MALA-N for 6 months. She is compliant, but she complained of missed periods. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

MALA-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). Despite high compliance, all contraceptive methods have a failure rate. The first consideration for a missed period in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy. Therefore, the next step is to estimate beta HCG levels to rule out pregnancy.

 

  • Beta HCG Estimation: This is essential to confirm or rule out pregnancy. Serum beta HCG can detect pregnancy as early as five days before the first missed period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This is not the initial step. It is more appropriate once pregnancy is confirmed or other issues are suspected.

 

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While some irregularity can occur with OCPs, pregnancy must be ruled out first.

 

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: These tests are used to evaluate ovarian function but are not appropriate for initial evaluation of a missed period in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills presents with a missed period, the first step is to rule out pregnancy by estimating beta HCG levels.

 

Ref: Page no 622, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: On the action line
Before the action line
On the alert line
After the alert line

questions.text: In a Partogram, where do you start plotting the cervical dilatation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) On the alert line

 

Explanation:

 

In the WHO modified partograph, labor progression is charted using alert and action lines. The cervical dilatation is plotted starting in the active phase of labor, typically at 4 cm dilation.

 

  • Alert Line: Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line.
  • Action Line: Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. On the action line: Plotting starts on the alert line, not the action line. The action line is used for intervention planning.

 

Option B. Before the action line: This is incorrect as the plotting starts on the alert line.

 

Option D. After the alert line: This is incorrect since plotting should start on the alert line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Partogram, cervical dilatation is first plotted on the alert line, which indicates the expected rate of progress in labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: Medroxy progesterone acetate

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

 

For postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia of the endometrium, the recommended treatment is a total hysterectomy. This approach is taken due to the increased risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma, especially given the presence of atypia and the patient's postmenopausal status.

 

  • Simple Hysterectomy: This involves the surgical removal of the uterus and is considered the ideal treatment for postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia to prevent the progression to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is a progestogen treatment used primarily for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, especially in women who desire to preserve fertility. It is not the ideal treatment for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is used for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia and as a conservative treatment for women wishing to preserve fertility. However, it is not the treatment of choice for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. It is typically reserved for more advanced or inoperable endometrial cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the ideal treatment is a total hysterectomy to prevent progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A couple with 2 children who are not able to conceive for over an year now present to the OPD. The male partner is diagnosed to be having hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism. Which of the following is not true? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low prolactin levels

 

Explanation:

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by a deficiency of gonadotropins (LH and FSH), which leads to low testosterone levels and impaired spermatogenesis. This condition often results in oligospermia or azoospermia, contributing to infertility. Additionally, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is frequently associated with hyperprolactinemia rather than low prolactin levels.

 

  • Low LH and FSH: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is marked by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) due to inadequate secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Low testosterone: The low levels of LH lead to reduced stimulation of Leydig cells in the testes, resulting in low testosterone levels.
  • Oligospermia: The low levels of FSH result in impaired spermatogenesis, often leading to oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • Low prolactin levels (Incorrect): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is associated with hyperprolactinemia, not low prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropins, further exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low LH and FSH: True. Gonadotropin deficiency is a hallmark of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option B. Low testosterone: True. The deficiency in LH leads to low testosterone production.

 

Option C. Oligospermia: True. The deficiency in FSH leads to impaired spermatogenesis, causing oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A male with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism will have high prolactin levels, low gonadotropins (LH and FSH), low testosterone, and often oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 199, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: According to the latest labour care guidelines, the partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 cm

 

  • Earlier, in the WHO modified partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In this partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per the WHO modified partograph, plotting is started at 4cm cervical dilatation, and the 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • As per the Labor Care Guide, plotting is started at 5 cm cervical dilatation

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele's rule? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) October 16

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day 
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 9 months and subtract 7 days from the date of the embryo transfer
  • For e.g. The EDD of this patient will be 16/10/2017.
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND.
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naegele's rule is a standard way of calculating the estimated date of delivery by adding 9 months and 7 days to the first day of the last menstrual period. This method assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 83, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma vulva

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is particularly useful in the management of vulval carcinomas among gynecological malignancies. The technique helps in determining the extent of lymph node involvement and thereby reduces unnecessary lymph node dissections and their associated complications, such as lymphedema. Sentinel lymph node biopsy can effectively identify the first lymph node (sentinel node) that drains the primary tumor, which is likely to be the first site of metastasis.

 

  • Lymphatic Mapping and Sentinel Node Biopsy:
    • Intraoperative Injection: Intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor to map lymphatic drainage.
    • Radioactive Tracer: Labeling tissues with a radioactive tracer and localizing with a hand-held detector.
    • Lymphoscintigraphy: This imaging technique has a 100% detection rate for sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Utility in Other Malignancies:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Penile carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma vagina: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is less commonly used in vaginal cancer compared to vulvar cancer.

 

Option C. Carcinoma cervix: While sentinel lymph node biopsy can be used, it is more established and routinely applied in vulvar cancer.

 

Option D. Carcinoma endometrium: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is also useful but not as prominently used as in vulvar carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in vulvar carcinoma among gynecological malignancies to reduce unnecessary lymph node dissection and its complications.

 

Ref: Page no 608, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: No need additional dose since she is ICT negative
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum irrespective of baby blood group
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group

questions.text: Rh negative mother, ICT negative was given Anti D during 28 weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following is the ideal one? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group

 

In Rh-negative women with an Rh-positive partner, Anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis is administered to prevent Rh sensitization. If the mother is ICT (Indirect Coombs Test) negative, an initial dose of Anti-D (300 mcg IM) is given at 28 weeks of gestation. Following delivery, an additional dose of Anti-D should be administered within 72 hours if the newborn is Rh-positive. This prevents the mother from forming antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells that might have entered her circulation during delivery.

 

  • Anti-D (300 mcg IM) at 28 weeks: Given if ICT is negative.
  • Postpartum dose within 72 hours: Required if the baby is Rh-positive. This dose is essential to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red cells that might have entered the mother's bloodstream during delivery.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. No need for an additional dose since she is ICT negative: Incorrect. Even if the ICT is negative, an additional dose is necessary postpartum if the baby is Rh-positive to prevent sensitization.

 

Option B. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum irrespective of baby blood group: Incorrect. The postpartum dose is only required if the baby is Rh-positive.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect as not all options are correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prophylaxis in Rh-negative women with an Rh-positive partner involves giving Anti-D (300 mcg IM) at 28 weeks (if ICT is negative) and repeating the dose within 72 hours after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive.

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

 

Explanation:

 

The next best step in managing a postmenopausal woman with a small (3 x 3 cm) smooth ovarian cyst is to measure CA-125 levels. CA-125 is a tumor marker used to assess the risk of ovarian cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst on ultrasound and the small size, the initial step is to evaluate CA-125 levels:

 

  • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups.
  • Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months: While reassurance is part of the management, initial evaluation with CA-125 is necessary to rule out malignancy before deciding on the follow-up schedule.

 

Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan: A CT scan is not the first-line investigation for a simple cyst with benign features. Initial evaluation with CA-125 is more appropriate.

 

Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst: This is invasive and not indicated for a small, benign-appearing cyst without other concerning features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple cysts in the post-menopausal age grp:

 

  • ≤ 1cm: Considered normal
  • ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks
  • > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation

 

Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased number of theca lutein cysts

 

Choriocarcinoma is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that arises from trophoblastic tissue following a molar pregnancy, miscarriage, abortion, or normal pregnancy. Indicators of choriocarcinoma include:

 

  • Persistently enlarged uterus: Indicates continued trophoblastic proliferation.
  • Plateau of high serum hCG: Persistent high levels of hCG after treatment suggest ongoing trophoblastic disease.
  • Sub-urethral nodule: A rare but specific sign of metastatic choriocarcinoma.

 

The presence of theca lutein cysts alone is not a specific indicator of choriocarcinoma, though these cysts can persist in cases of GTN. The increased number of theca lutein cysts is associated with molar pregnancies and persistent GTN but not specifically indicative of choriocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistently enlarged uterus: This is a common finding in choriocarcinoma due to persistent trophoblastic tissue.

 

Option C. Plateau of high serum hCG: This is a hallmark of choriocarcinoma as it indicates continued activity of the trophoblastic cells.

 

Option D. Sub-urethral nodule: This can be a sign of metastasis from choriocarcinoma. Indicates metastasis of choriocarcinoma forming a firm palpable mass beneath urethral nodule

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indicators of choriocarcinoma include persistently enlarged uterus, plateau of high serum hCG, and sub-urethral nodules, but not an increased number of theca lutein cysts alone.

 

Ref: Page no 361, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 90 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
80 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
100 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

questions.text: Which of the following fits into the criteria of severe variable deceleration, variations less than: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds.

 

Severe variable decelerations in fetal heart rate (FHR) are characterized by a significant reduction in the heart rate below the baseline. The specific criterion for a severe variable deceleration is when the heart rate drops below 70 beats per minute and this reduction persists for at least 60 seconds.

 

Variable decelerations are sudden decreases in the FHR that occur with or without contractions. They are commonly caused by umbilical cord compression, which impedes blood flow through the umbilical vein and arteries, leading to a reduction in fetal cardiac output. This type of deceleration is defined by a decrease of at least 15 beats per minute below the baseline and typically lasts between 15 seconds and less than 2 minutes.

 

Classification of Variable Decelerations:

 

  • Mild: Heart rate decreases to greater than 80 beats per minute regardless of duration, or decelerations lasting less than 30 seconds regardless of the heart rate, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting less than 60 seconds.
  • Moderate: Heart rate decreases to more than 70 beats per minute for 30-60 seconds, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting more than 60 seconds.
  • Severe: Heart rate decreases to less than 70 beats per minute for an extended duration (at least 60 seconds).

 

(70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds) meets the criteria for severe variable deceleration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe variable decelerations are defined by a fetal heart rate dropping to less than 70 beats per minute for at least 60 seconds, typically due to umbilical cord compression.

choices.text: Placenta membranacea
Placenta succenturiata
Circumvallate placenta

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

 

  • It is mentioned here that the placenta expelled looked normal and intact
  • In such a case, if there is a retained component, it could be a succenturiate lobe
  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a placenta with an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue located a few centimeters away.
  • The ancillary lobes can be associated with complications such as placenta previa, vasa previa, postpartum hemorrhage or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta membranacea:

 

  • Placenta membranacea is a rare placental disorder characterized by the presence of fetal membranes (complete or partially) covered by chorionic villi.
  • Associated with painless vaginal bleeding in the second and third trimester
  • This condition can be associated with other placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or accreta.
  • Perinatal outcome may include stillbirth, preterm delivery, or neonatal death.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta:

 

  • Uncommon variation in placental morphology in which a thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.
  • The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta
  • Associated with Abortion, Hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery vaginal discharge), Antepartum hemorrhage, Growth retardation of the baby, Preterm delivery and Retained placenta or membranes.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta:

 

  • The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete.
  • The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between
  • Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disappear from view
  • The peripheral zone outside the ring is thicker and the edge is elevated and rounded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which procedure amongst the following has the highest probability of ureteric injury? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the radical nature of the procedure. Wertheim's hysterectomy, also known as radical hysterectomy, involves extensive dissection and removal of not only the uterus but also the surrounding tissues, including the parametria and the upper part of the vagina. This extensive dissection increases the risk of ureteric injury.

 

However, it's important to note that while Wertheim's hysterectomy carries a higher individual risk for ureteric injury due to its radical nature, the most common cause of ureteric injury overall is abdominal hysterectomy, simply because it is the most commonly performed type of hysterectomy.

 

The overall incidence of ureteric injury in all pelvic operations is about 0.5-1%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal hysterectomy: Although it is the most common cause of ureteric injury due to its high frequency, the individual risk per procedure is lower than that of Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Vaginal hysterectomy: This procedure has a lower risk of ureteric injury compared to abdominal and Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Anterior colporrhaphy: This procedure, which is used to repair the anterior vaginal wall, has a much lower risk of ureteric injury compared to hysterectomy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the extensive dissection involved in the procedure.

 

The risk of ureteric injury is highest with a radical hysterectomy followed laparoscopic or robotic hysterectomy followed by abdominal hysterectomy and least risk is with vaginal hysterectomy

 

Ref: TeLinde’s Operative gynecology 12th edition

choices.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3
Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will have? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3

 

Explanation:

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triple test results for Down's syndrome typically show low MSAFP, high hCG, and low uE3.

 

Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Repeat Colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came for routine PAP smear testing. The report came as HSIL. On colposcopy and biopsy, it was confirmed to be carcinoma in situ. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conization

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix is classified as Stage 0 cancer. In a young woman with stage 0 cervical cancer, the management of choice is conization. Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix. This procedure serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes:

 

  • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear.
  • Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical treatment and is generally reserved for cases where there is invasive cancer or other indications. It is not the first-line treatment for CIS in a young woman.

 

Option C. Repeat colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months: In the case of confirmed carcinoma in situ, conization is preferred. There is no need of repeat colpobiopsy 

 

Option D. HPV DNA testing: This test is used for screening and risk assessment but is not a treatment for confirmed carcinoma in situ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conization, which involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix, is the management of choice for carcinoma in situ in young women. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic if histopathology shows clear margins.

 

 

Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour
Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification specifically includes:

 

  • Nulliparous: A woman who has never given birth before.
  • Singleton: A pregnancy involving only one fetus.
  • Cephalic: The fetal presentation is head-down.
  • ≥37 weeks: The pregnancy is at or beyond 37 weeks of gestation.
  • Spontaneous labour: Labour onset is spontaneous, not induced or via cesarean section.

 

This classification is used to categorize pregnant women for analyzing obstetric outcomes, interventions, and cesarean section rates. The Modified Robson’s classification is a system developed by the World Health Organization to help in understanding and comparing cesarean section rates and labor outcomes across different settings.

 

 

Robson’s 10 groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour: This option describes Class 2 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Option C. Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour: This option describes Class 3 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Option D. Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour: This option describes Class 4 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/259512/9789241513197-eng.pdf?sequence=1

choices.text: Superficial transverse perineal

questions.text: The deepest part of perineal body injury, which causes cystocele, enterocoele and urethral descent is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pubococcygeus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle.
  • Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.
  • The levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • Weakening of this muscle decreases support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bulbospongiosus, Option C. ischiocavernosus and Option D. superficial transverse perineal are all superficial muscles and their damage does not result in uterovaginal descent

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supports of the vagal have been described by Delancey as shown below and defects in these lead to different levels of uterovaginal prolapse
    • Defect in Level 1 support: Vaginal apical prolapse and uterine prolapse
    • Defect in level 2 support: Cystocele and Rectocele
    • Defect in level 3 support: urethrocele and deficient perineal body

 

 

Ref: Page no 544, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent post-partum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gentle massage of uterus

 

AMTSL

 

Purpose: To prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), a major cause of maternal death.

 

  1. Give a uterotonic drug
    • Oxytocin 10 IU IM immediately after the birth of the baby
    • This helps the uterus contract and reduce bleeding
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
    • Gently pull the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus to help deliver the placenta
    • Only if trained and placenta is ready to come
  3. Intermittent uterine tone assessment

 

Delayed cord clamping

 

  • Wait 1–3 minutes before clamping the umbilical cord
  • Improves baby’s iron stores and reduces anemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonic within 1 minute of delivery: This is a critical step in AMTSL to prevent PPH by promoting uterine contractions.

 

Option B. Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord: Delayed cord clamping (after 1 to 3 minutes) is recommended for all births to enhance neonatal outcomes

 

Option D. Controlled cord traction: This is a part of AMTSL to aid in the delivery of the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active management of the third stage of labor includes the administration of a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and assessing uterine tone rather than sustained uterine massage for all women who have received a uterotonic.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/120082/WHO_RHR_14.20_eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: HPV Nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6, 11, 16, 18

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent HPV vaccine effective against 9 serotypes of the virus
  • These include: 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.merckvaccines.com/gardasil9/

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. This approach allows for the direct sampling of the lesion to assess for malignancy or other pathological changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conisation: Conisation is an excisional procedure that is typically performed once biopsy-proven cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step for a visible mass with postcoital bleeding.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure used for treating CIN1 or 2. It is not suitable for initial diagnosis or for lesions suspected of being malignant.

 

Option D. Pap smear: A Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. It is a screening tool and not diagnostic for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a symptomatic patient with a visible cervical lesion and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is the appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The following instrument is used for……:  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAP smear

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shown is that of Ayre's spatula which is used for preparing PAP smear.
  • It is used to scrape the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix while preparing a Pap smear.
  • A cytobrush is used to take endocervical samples
  • The smear is fixed with 95% ethanol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIA: This is Visual Inspection under Acetic Acid. This is done by applying acetic acid on the cervix. Any acetowhite area is suspicious for dysplasia. It is done in low resource settings.

 

Option B. VILI: Visual inspection under Lugol Iodine: This is done by applying Lugol’s iodine on the cervix. A dysplastic area will not take up iodine. It is also done in low resource settings.

 

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is a magnified view of the cervix. It is done in patients with abnormal pap smear/ HPV +Ve/ VIA +ve or VILI +ve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ayre's spatula is used for preparing a Pap smear by scraping cells from the cervix for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Page no 325, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Endodermal sinus tumor
Malignant teratoma
Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysgerminoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass with raised LDH points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas usually arise in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. They currently account for approximately one-third of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors and are the most common malignant ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor: This is typically associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), not LDH.

 

Option C. Malignant teratoma: This type of tumor does not typically present with elevated LDH as the sole abnormal marker.

 

Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: This epithelial ovarian tumor is usually associated with elevated CA-125, not LDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminoma is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with an ovarian mass and elevated LDH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) III

 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasms (GTN) are classified into stages based on their extent of spread:

 

  • Stage I: The disease is confined to the uterus.
  • Stage II: The disease has spread outside the uterus but remains confined to the genital structures.
  • Stage III: The disease has metastasized to the lungs, which is a significant indicator of progression beyond the local genital structures.
  • Stage IV: The disease has spread to other distant sites beyond the lungs, such as the liver or brain.

 

Since the case involves metastasis specifically to the lungs, it falls into Stage III, which is characterized by such pulmonary involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastasis to the lungs in gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is classified as Stage III.

 

Ref: Page no 364, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with various structural, behavioral, and developmental anomalies due to prenatal alcohol exposure. One of the key features of FAS is microcephaly, not macrocephaly. High levels of alcohol ingestion during pregnancy can severely impact embryonic and fetal development.

 

The presence of at least one of the following characteristics is indicative of fetal alcohol syndrome:

 

  • Growth restriction: Can occur before and/or after birth.
  • Facial anomalies: These include small palpebral fissures, indistinct or absent philtrum, epicanthic folds, flattened nasal bridge, short length of nose, thin upper lip, low-set and unparallel ears, and retarded midfacial development.
  • CNS dysfunction: Includes microcephaly, mental retardation, and abnormal neurobehavioral development such as attention deficit with hyperactivity.

 

Other features that may be seen in FAS include:

 

  • Incomplete holoprosencephaly: A condition where the forebrain does not completely divide into two hemispheres.
  • Agenesis of the corpus callosum and cerebellar vermis: Developmental anomalies where these brain structures are partially or completely absent.
  • Cardiac anomalies: Such as ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Macrocephaly is not seen in fetal alcohol syndrome; instead, microcephaly is characteristic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a characteristic finding in fetal alcohol syndrome due to developmental anomalies.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: This is commonly seen in fetal alcohol syndrome and is one of the diagnostic features.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: Incomplete holoprosencephaly can be seen in fetal alcohol syndrome as a result of severe midline developmental anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

Ref: Page no 397, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The given instrument is used in: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The instrument shown is a Doyen's retractor, which is specifically used in cesarean sections. It plays a crucial role during the surgical procedure by retracting the bladder to provide proper exposure of the lower uterine segment. This retraction helps in ensuring a clear view and access to the uterus while minimizing the risk of bladder injury. The Doyen's retractor is used once the utero-vesical fold of peritoneum is opened and the bladder is dissected away from the lower uterine segment. It holds the bladder away from the site of the uterine incision, facilitating a safer and more efficient cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal hysterectomy: Involves the removal of the uterus through the vaginal canal and typically uses different types of retractors and instruments designed for vaginal access, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Option C. Manchester operation: This is a surgical procedure used to correct uterovaginal prolapse and does not involve the use of Doyen's retractor.

 

Option D. Fothergill's surgery: This is performed for uterovaginal prolapse and uses different instruments tailored for vaginal repairs, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doyen's retractor is used during cesarean sections to retract the bladder and prevent bladder injury while providing exposure of the lower uterine segment.

 

Ref: Page no 751, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Ascending aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Superior vena-caval syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right occipito-anterior

 

The Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position means the fetal occiput (the back of the head) is directed towards the mother's right side and anterior (towards the front of the pelvis). This position indicates that the fetus is facing towards the mother's right side with its back towards the front of the pelvis.

 

In fetal positions:

 

  • Right occipito-anterior (ROA): The occiput is on the right side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-anterior (LOA): The occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Right occipito-posterior (ROP): The occiput is on the right side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-posterior (LOP): The occiput is on the left side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Right occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the right side but towards the back of the pelvis, not the front.

 

Option B. Left occipito-anterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.

 

Option C. Left occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side but towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position, the fetal occiput is directed towards the mother's right side and the anterior part of the pelvis.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • Studdiford Criteria is for diagnosis of Primary abdominal pregnancy
    • Both tubes and ovaries normal with no marks of injury
    • Utero-peritoneal fistula should not be seen
    • The placenta should be attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg Criteria: Spiegelberg Criteria is for Ovarian ectopic

 

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestation sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • The gestation sac in the ovary must be connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall on histopathology

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Rubin criteria is for Cervical pregnancy

 

Option D. Ring of fire: Ring of fire is a sign seen on USG-Color doppler in an unruptured tubal ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

Studdiford Criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. This criterion involves:

 

  1. Ensuring that both fallopian tubes and ovaries are normal with no signs of injury.
  2. Confirming that no utero-peritoneal fistula is present.
  3. Verifying that the placenta is attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface.

 

These criteria help distinguish primary abdominal pregnancy from other types of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 219, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

choices.text: At the onset of labor
40 weeks

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with cardiac disease involves switching from warfarin to heparin at specific times to minimize the risk of complications to the fetus and to prepare for delivery.

 

  • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks: According to guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians, pregnant women on warfarin therapy should switch to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation. This is done to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

 

Guidelines Summary:

 

  1. Early Pregnancy (up to 12 weeks):
    • Discontinue warfarin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed, especially if the warfarin dose is >5mg/day, due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy.
    • Replace with heparin (5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).
  2. After 12 Weeks to 36 Weeks:
    • Warfarin can be resumed after the 12th week and continued up to 36 weeks.
  3. At 36 Weeks:
    • Switch from warfarin to heparin (either unfractionated or LMWH).
  4. Just Before Delivery:
    • Discontinue heparin just before delivery.
  5. Postpartum:
    • Restart heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section.
    • Warfarin therapy can also be safely resumed during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The final switch from warfarin to heparin in pregnant women with cardiac disease is advised at 36 weeks of gestation to minimize the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of labor? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO Recommendations 2018 for the intrapartum second stage of labor emphasize the importance of a positive birth experience. The guidelines suggest manual support to the perineum to maintain the flexion of the fetal head, which helps in reducing perineal trauma.

 

WHO Recommendations 2018 (Intrapartum Second Stage):

 

Recommended:

 

  • Duration of the second stage in primigravida: up to 3 hours; in multigravida: up to 2 hours
  • Allowing the birthing position of choice
  • Encouraging the mother to follow her own urge to push
  • Reducing perineal trauma by using techniques such as hands-on guarding, warm compresses, and perineal massage

 

Not recommended:

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: This is not recommended as a routine practice according to WHO guidelines. Episiotomy should only be performed when clinically indicated.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This is incorrect. Warm compresses to the perineum are recommended to help reduce perineal trauma.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: The WHO guidelines recommend allowing the woman to choose her birthing position, rather than mandating the lithotomy position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Manual support to the perineum and maintaining the flexion of the fetal head are part of the WHO recommendations for the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma and ensure a positive birth experience.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: What does this Cardio-Tocography show?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deceleration

 

Explanation:

 

The Cardio-Tocography (CTG) in question shows decelerations, which are characterized by a drop in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by at least 15 beats per minute (bpm) lasting for at least 15 seconds.

 

Types of Decelerations on CTG:

 

  1. Early Deceleration:
    • The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the uterine contraction.
    • Caused by head compression during contractions.
    • Commonly observed in the second stage of labor.
  2. Late Deceleration:
    • The nadir of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
    • Indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency, which can lead to fetal distress or hypoxia.
    • Considered an ominous sign and requires prompt evaluation and intervention.
  3. Variable Deceleration:
    • There is no fixed relationship between the deceleration and uterine contractions.
    • Caused by umbilical cord compression, often seen with oligohydramnios.
    • Significant if persistent, with FHR <70 bpm for more than 60 seconds.
  4. Prolonged Deceleration:
    • Occurs when the deceleration lasts beyond 2 minutes but less than 10 minutes.
    • May indicate acute fetal hypoxia, such as with cord prolapse or intrapartum abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acceleration: This would show an increase in the fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Normal: A normal CTG would not show any decelerations or would show a typical pattern of fetal heart rate variability and accelerations.

 

Option D. Deceleration followed by acceleration: This pattern would indicate a combination of deceleration and acceleration, which is not specified here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decelerations on a Cardio-Tocography indicate a decrease in fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, with different types signifying various conditions and levels of concern.

 

Ref: Page no 994, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Parvovirus
Toxoplasma
HIV

questions.text: Which of these is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus

 

  • Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis. (Non immune hydrops)
  • Parvovirus B19 infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells and causes anemia.
  • Severe anemia leads to high-output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. CMV: Typically causes peri-ventricular calcifications in the fetus.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Causes:  hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification, microcephaly, seizures and mental retardation in the newborn.

 

Option D. HIV: Vertical transmission of HIV from mother to infant can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis due to its effect on fetal erythroid progenitor cells, leading to severe anemia and subsequent high-output cardiac failure.

 

Ref: Page no 347, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

 

The Anti-D vaccine (anti-D immunoglobulin) is typically administered to prevent Rh sensitization in Rh-negative women who might be exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood. It is given to protect against the formation of anti-Rh antibodies that could affect future pregnancies. The vaccine is not given after an intrauterine transfusion because this procedure is performed to treat severe fetal anemia in cases where the mother is Rh-positive or the indirect Coombs test (ICT) is positive, indicating that the mother has already been sensitized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: Anti-D vaccine is given after amniocentesis to prevent Rh sensitization, as the procedure can cause fetal blood to mix with maternal blood.

 

Option B. Manual removal of placenta: Anti-D vaccine is administered after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization, as this procedure can result in significant feto-maternal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. MTP at 63 days: Anti-D vaccine is given after medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to prevent Rh sensitization if the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-D vaccine is not given after intrauterine transfusion, as this procedure is used to treat severe fetal anemia and does not require further prophylaxis against Rh sensitization.

 

Ref: Page no 919, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day she came back with fever, tachycardia and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. Diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cortical vein thrombosis

 

  • The given clinical situation likely suggests Cortical Vein Thrombosis.
  • Cortical Vein thrombosis
    • Risk factors:
      • Pregnancy and puerperium
      • Oral contraceptives
      • Pro thrombotic conditions
    • Clinical presentation
      • Highly variable
      • Headache is the most common symptom.
      • With or without
      • Vomiting
      • Papilledema
      • Focal deficits
    • Investigation
      • Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive
      • CT - normal in 30 % of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage unlikely as there are no focal deficits

 

Option B. Meningitis: Meningitis would have presented with neck rigidity / photophobia and early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

 

Option C. Acute Migraine: Acute Migraine does not present with seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cortical/ Cerebral vein thrombosis should be thought of in a patient with headache and seizures/ other neurological deficits following delivery

choices.text: Continue same diet

questions.text: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie requirements in this trimester? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue same diet

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half. During the first trimester, there is no need for additional calories. The caloric increase is recommended as follows:

 

  • 0 Kcal in 1st trimester
  • 340 Kcal in 2nd trimester
  • 452 Kcal in 3rd trimester

 

In this question, extra calories in the 1st trimester are asked, so the answer will be no additional requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

Page no 487, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naloxone

 

Explanation:

 

Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.

 

Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type of maternal pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix
 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cervical length: This is a component of the Modified Bishop score, measuring the length of the cervix in centimeters.

 

Option C. Cervical position: This is a component of the Bishop score, assessing the position of the cervix relative to the vaginal canal.

 

Option D. Dilatation of cervix: This is a component of the Bishop score, measuring the extent to which the cervix has opened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Type of maternal pelvis is not a component of the Bishop score.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A young female has history of a induced abortion at 11 weeks. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion and subsequent dilation and curettage (D&C) is typically due to intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome.

 

  • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome): This condition involves the formation of scar tissue within the uterine cavity, leading to amenorrhea or menstrual abnormalities. It commonly occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C.
    • Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome.
    • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.

Other options:

 

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: This would typically be associated with abnormal levels of pituitary hormones, including FSH. The normal FSH level (6 mIU/ml) suggests that pituitary function is intact.

 

Option B. Ovarian dysfunction: This condition would generally present with elevated or depressed levels of FSH and other ovarian hormones. The normal FSH level suggests that ovarian function is likely normal.

 

Option C. First pregnancy: In pregnancy, FSH levels are very low (<0.1 mIU/ml). The FSH level of 6 mIU/ml makes this an unlikely cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a history of spontaneous abortion and D&C is usually due to intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), diagnosed by hysteroscopy and treated with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.
