questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried female has come to the gynae OPD for cervical cancer vaccination. Which is preferred? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gardasil

 

Explanation:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for cervical cancer prevention. It is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that provides protection against four serotypes of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV): 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

  • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil:
    • 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts.
    • 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.

 

Gardasil is administered as an intramuscular injection with a recommended schedule of three doses (0, 2, and 6 months).

 

Available HPV Vaccines:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 16 and 18.
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  3. Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent, covers serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biovac: This is a vaccine for Hepatitis A, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option C. Rabivac: This is a rabies vaccine for animals, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tvac: This is a tetanus vaccine, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for preventing cervical cancer and related HPV diseases, covering serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/teams/immunization-vaccines-and-biologicals/diseases/human-papillomavirus-vaccines-(HPV)

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that there is cord prolapse. What should be the next immediate step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put her in Trendelenburg position

 

Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part of the fetus in the birth canal, leading to compression of the cord. This compression can restrict blood flow and oxygen to the fetus, causing fetal distress or hypoxia.

 

The immediate management of cord prolapse includes:

 

  • Relieving pressure off the cord: This is crucial to prevent fetal hypoxia. This can be achieved by positioning the patient in a way that minimizes pressure on the cord.
  • Trendelenburg position: This position involves tilting the patient’s body with the head down and the pelvis up. This helps to shift the fetal presenting part off the prolapsed cord and relieves compression.
  • Left lateral position or All-fours position: Alternative positions can also help in relieving pressure on the cord.

 

While preparing for an emergency cesarean section (LSCS) to deliver the fetus urgently, these positions and techniques are used to temporarily alleviate the pressure on the cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gently replace the cord inside the vagina: Attempting to reposition the cord is not recommended as it can cause further damage or spasm of the vessels in the cord.

 

Option B. Inform the doctor and shift to OT: While informing the doctor and preparing for cesarean delivery is necessary, immediate steps to relieve cord compression should be taken first.

 

Option D. Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation: This may be done, but the primary focus should be on relieving the pressure on the cord immediately to prevent fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of cord prolapse, placing the patient in Trendelenburg position helps to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a critical step in managing the emergency until a cesarean section can be performed.

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: The quantity of sperms
The motility of sperms
The morphology of sperms
The number of sperm

questions.text: Identify the best parameter to assess in case of male infertility? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The morphology of sperms

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperms is considered the best parameter to assess male infertility. Sperm morphology refers to the size and shape of sperm, and abnormalities in these characteristics can significantly affect a man's fertility.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sperm Morphology: Characterization of normal sperm morphology shows improved correlation with fertilization rates during IVF cycles. A significantly decreased fertilization rate is observed when the normal morphology of the sample falls below the strict criteria of 4%.
  • Sperm Quantity and Number: While the quantity and number of sperms are important, they are not as critical as morphology in determining fertility potential.
  • Sperm Motility: Motility is also a crucial factor, but morphology has a stronger correlation with fertilization success.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The quantity of sperms: Refers to the total volume of ejaculate, which is less indicative of fertility compared to morphology.

 

Option B. The motility of sperms: Important for fertility but not as strongly correlated with fertilization success as morphology.

 

Option D. The number of sperm: Similar to the quantity, the number is important but does not correlate as closely with fertilization rates as morphology does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most significant parameter for assessing male infertility, as it closely correlates with fertilization rates during assisted reproductive techniques like IVF.

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal lady is detected by endometrial hyperplasia with atypia what is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia should be offered a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the very high risk of progression to malignancy. This approach effectively removes the source of hyperplasia and eliminates the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: High dose Progesterones can be used to manage endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, but this is not the recommended approach for atypical hyperplasia in postmenopausal women.

 

Option C. Mirena: The LNG-IUS (Mirena) can be recommended for those who want to preserve fertility and for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. However, it is not suitable for postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure may be used for diagnostic purposes but is not treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical endometrial hyperplasia should undergo a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Ref: Page no 329, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score/formula? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G4P1 A2 L1

 

Determining the Parity Index/ Obstetric Formula

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

The obstetric score here is G4P1A2L1.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. But if it results in 2 living children it will be Live 2.

choices.text: Amoxicillin
Fluconazole
Metronidazole

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of greenish discharge per vagina and on examination she had a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the treatment for her? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of greenish-yellow discharge and a strawberry cervix is characteristic of trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The diagnostic feature of trichomoniasis includes the presence of motile flagellate organisms on a wet mount microscopy.

 

  • Characteristic findings:
    • Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow
    • On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina
    • pH: >5
    • Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism

 

Treatment:

 

  • The recommended treatment for trichomoniasis is metronidazole. It can be administered as a single dose of 2g or 200mg TDS for 7 days.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: This antibiotic is used to treat various bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections, but it is not the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis.

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is used for bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis.

 

Option C. Fluconazole: This antifungal medication is used to treat candidiasis, not trichomoniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strawberry cervix and greenish-yellow vaginal discharge are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which is treated with metronidazole.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strawberry cervix and vagina are characteristic of Trichomoniasis

 

Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower -CG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct as PAPP-A is not part of the quadruple test and it typically decreases in Down syndrome.

 

Option C. Lower B-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), the quadruple test shows elevated β hCG and Inhibin A, and decreased AFP and uE3.

 

Ref: Page no 863, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 39 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The appropriate timing of delivery in a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) whose blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin is at or after 39 weeks of gestation. This recommendation is based on the following considerations:

 

  • Lung Maturity: GDM pregnancies are associated with a delay in fetal lung maturity. Routine delivery before 39 weeks is generally not recommended to avoid respiratory complications in the newborn.
  • Induction of Labor: If the patient with well-controlled GDM has not delivered spontaneously by 39 weeks, induction of labor should be scheduled at or after 39 weeks to minimize the risks associated with GDM and to ensure fetal maturity.

 

Other important points in GDM:

 

  • Avoid Past Dates: Delivery should not be delayed beyond the expected due date to prevent complications.
  • Anticipate Shoulder Dystocia: There is an increased risk of shoulder dystocia in infants of mothers with GDM.
  • Prophylactic Cesarean Section (LSCS): Considered if the estimated fetal weight is greater than 4.5 kg to avoid complications during vaginal delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with well-controlled gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) on insulin, the appropriate gestational age for delivery is at or after 39 weeks to ensure fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/National_Guidelines_for_Diagnosis_&_Management_of_Gestational_Diabetes_Mellitus.pdf

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady nearing her due date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and told the intern that the head is at +1 station. Where is the exact position of head? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Just below ischial spine

 

In obstetrics, the station of the fetal head during labor is measured relative to the ischial spines of the maternal pelvis. The ischial spines are bony landmarks that serve as reference points.

 

  • 0 Station: The presenting part of the fetus is at the level of the ischial spines.
  • Positive Stations (+1 to +5): These indicate the presenting part is below the ischial spines. For example, +1 station means the presenting part is 1 cm below the ischial spines.
  • Negative Stations (-1 to -5): These indicate the presenting part is above the ischial spines.

 

At +1 station, the fetal head is just below the ischial spine by 1 cm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At the perineum: This would indicate a more advanced station, such as +4 or +5.

 

Option C. Just above the ischial spine: This would be a negative station (e.g., -1 or -2).

 

Option D. High up in the false pelvis: This would correspond to a much higher, negative station.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the station of the head is described during a vaginal exam, it is with respect to the ischial spine:

 

  • The ischial spine is taken as 0 station.
  • Anything above the ischial spine is denoted as a negative station (-).
  • Anything below the ischial spine is denoted as a positive station (+).

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate termination

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described indicates fetal compromise, specifically with the findings of oligohydramnios (AFI = 5) and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler. These are signs of severe placental insufficiency and fetal distress.

 

  • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth.
  • Management:
    • Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks: This is not appropriate because the immediate risk to the fetus requires prompt delivery.

 

Option C. Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion: Continuous monitoring is insufficient in this scenario as the condition indicates severe fetal distress requiring urgent intervention.

 

Option D. Terminate after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is not appropriate due to the immediate risk of fetal compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe fetal compromise indicated by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler, especially beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate termination of the pregnancy is warranted to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential stillbirth.

 

Ref: Page no 2141, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

 

Contraceptive methods can be classified into temporary (reversible) and permanent (irreversible) methods.

 

  • Permanent Methods (Irreversible):
    • Laparoscopic Tubal Ligation: This is a surgical procedure where the fallopian tubes are cut, tied, or sealed to prevent pregnancy permanently. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception as it is intended to be a permanent solution for women who do not wish to have more children.
  • Temporary Methods (Reversible):
    • Copper-T (Intrauterine Device - IUD): A long-term but reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.
    • Implanon (Subdermal Contraceptive Implant): A long-term reversible method that can be removed to restore fertility.
    • LNG-IUD (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine Device): Another long-term reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent (irreversible) method of contraception.

 

Ref: Page no 611, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs
Two doses 12 hrs apart
Three doses 12 hrs apart
None of the above

questions.text: For emergency contraception, a single tab of 0.75 mg of LNG was taken, it should be followed by which of the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs

 

Explanation:

 

  • In this case, the 2nd dose of LNG 0.75 mg (levonorgestrel) is taken after 12 hours.
  • One tablet of LNG 0.75mg should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and another 12 hours later.
  • Alternately, two tablets (of 0.75mg) or a single 1.5mg tablet can be taken as a single dose.
  • The tablets can be offered up to 72h of an act of unprotected intercourse, but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

 

Other emergency contraceptives available:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency contraception using levonorgestrel requires a follow-up dose of 0.75 mg taken 12 hours after the initial dose to ensure efficacy.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract
It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis; her physician advises for a Pap smear. She asks you regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your appropriate response? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a screening test for cervical cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer.
  • A cervical smear is prepared using the pap test which is sent for cytological examination
  • The presence of malignant cells on Pap smear requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage, etc.

 

Prerequisites:

 

  • It should be done prior to vaginal examination
  • Lubricants should not be used
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test
  • The ideal time is around ovulation
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas vaginalis: Trichomonas vaginalis is diagnosed by seeing the flagellated organism (T. vaginalis) on a vaginal smear

 

Option C. It helps to diagnose cervical cancer in her genital tract: A pap smear is specifically for cervical cancer screening and also for recurrence from the vaginal vault following hysterectomy for CIN/ cervical cancer.

 

Option D. It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her: A pap smear can detect associated genital infections especially cervical infections but is not routinely used for this purpose

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer, used to identify abnormal cells in the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 113, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition.

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be normal in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S3

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to accommodate the increased blood volume and cardiac output required to support both the mother and the developing fetus. One of the normal physiological changes includes the presence of the S3 heart sound.

 

  • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.

 

Other heart sounds mentioned are not typically considered normal in pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. S4 Heart Sound: The S4 sound, or atrial gallop, is generally associated with pathological conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy or myocardial ischemia. It is rare in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is usually indicative of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and is not normal in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Pericardial Knock: This is a sound heard in cases of constrictive pericarditis and is not a normal finding in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The S3 heart sound is considered normal during pregnancy due to the increased blood volume and rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles.

 

Ref: Page no 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A primigravida came with 6 cm cervical dilatation and a contraction rate of 3/10 minutes. Which stage of labor is she in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st stage

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is in the 1st stage of labor, which is defined as the onset of true labor pain until the full dilation of the cervix. The 1st stage of labor can be further classified as:

 

  • Latent phase: Cervical dilation of less than 5 cm.
  • Active phase: Cervical dilation of 5 cm or more.

 

Earlier, this cutoff for the active phase was considered at 4 cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd stage: The second stage of labor begins with complete cervical dilation and ends with the delivery of the fetus. Since the cervix is not fully dilated (10 cm), the patient is not in the second stage.

 

Option C. 3rd stage: The third stage of labor is characterized by the delivery of the placenta. The patient is not in this stage as the fetus has not yet been delivered.

 

Option D. 4th stage: The fourth stage is a stage of observation for at least an hour after the full expulsion of the placenta. The patient is not in this stage as the delivery process is still ongoing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st stage of labor, which involves cervical dilation from the onset of true labor pain until full dilation, is divided into latent and active phases, with the active phase beginning at 5 cm dilation.

 

Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: 10% buffered formalin
95% ethyl alcohol
None of the above

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. This fixative preserves the cellular detail necessary for accurate cytological evaluation by preventing cellular autolysis and degradation. The use of 95% ethyl alcohol ensures that the cells maintain their morphology, which is critical for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma.

 

  • 95% Ethyl Alcohol: This is the standard fixative for Pap smears, ensuring optimal preservation of cellular details.
  • Ethanol Spray: In modern practice, an ethanol spray fixative is available, which can be conveniently used in an office setting to fix the smear immediately after it is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% buffered formalin: This fixative is typically used for histological specimens rather than cytological smears like the Pap test.

 

Option C. Air dried: Air drying is not recommended for Pap smears as it can cause cellular distortion and artifacts, which complicate the interpretation of the smear.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as 95% ethyl alcohol is the correct fixative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.

 

Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start plotting the graph? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4cm

 

  • In the WHO modified partograph, labor ((Cervical dilatation vs time)  is plotted on a graph and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In the WHO modified partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm so when answering a question read carefully what is asked – WHO modified partograph or WHO Labor care guide

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plotting on the partograph should start at 4 cm cervical dilatation during the active phase of labor.

 

Ref: Page no 152, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 7th edition

choices.text: Metronidazole
Fluconazole
Clindamycin

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of pregnant woman with bacterial vaginosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis (BV) in pregnant women. This choice is based on its efficacy in addressing the anaerobic bacterial overgrowth that characterizes BV. It is generally prescribed as 200 mg three times daily for 7 days during pregnancy. While Clindamycin is also used for BV and can be an alternative, Metronidazole remains the preferred treatment due to its effectiveness and established safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for the treatment of fungal infections like candidiasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option C. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for BV, especially if Metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, Metronidazole is typically preferred.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: This antibiotic is generally used for various bacterial infections but is not the first choice for BV. It is not typically used for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months amenorrhea. Her FSH and LH were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

 

Explanation

 

  • Since LH and FSH are elevated above the normal value, the possibility of a pregnancy can be ruled out as FSH and LH levels fall to very low levels in pregnancy
  • The first step in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea after ruling out pregnancy is to do a progesterone challenge test i.e. to see if she bleeds after a challenge of progesterone.
  • If she bleeds, the diagnosis is anovulation like in PCOS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estimate serum estradiol values: Serum estradiol level measurement has no role in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea

 

Option D. Do a urine pregnancy test: FSH levels in pregnancy are very very low so pregnancy is unlikely; otherwise the most common cause of secondary amenorrhoea is pregnancy

 

Option C. Check USG for Polycystic ovaries: This is done if the patient bleeds following progesterone withdrawal as it determines the cause of anovular cycles

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is defined as a period of amenorrhoea of 6 months
  • Pregnancy needs to be ruled out
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea after ruling out pregnancy is anovulation (PCOS) which can be determined by the progesterone withdrawal test

 

Ref: Page no 457, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Episiotomy scissors

 

The instrument shown in the picture is an episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is designed to prevent the extension of a pelvic tear into the anal margins and to avoid obstetric anal sphincter injuries or complete perineal tears.

 

An episiotomy is not given routinely. Its use should be restricted to specific situations such as:

 

  • Macrosomia: When the baby is larger than average.
  • After coming head of breech: To facilitate the delivery of the head in a breech birth.
  • Instrumental delivery: When tools like forceps or vacuum are used to assist in delivery.
  • Shoulder dystocia: A delivery complication where the baby's shoulders get stuck.
  • Rigid perineum: Often seen in primigravida, where the perineum does not stretch easily.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mayo scissors: General-purpose surgical scissors used for cutting tissues.

 

Option B. Curved scissors: Scissors with a curved blade, used for various surgical procedures but not specifically for episiotomy.

 

Option C. Suture remover: Scissors designed specifically for removing sutures, not for performing an episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum to facilitate childbirth and prevent severe perineal tears. Their use is restricted to specific obstetric situations to avoid unnecessary complications.

 

Ref: Page no 755 Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pawlik grip

 

  • The Leopold's third manuever is also called the Pawlik's grip.
  • It is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip / Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Second Pelvic grip: This is incorrect. The second pelvic grip, also known as the fourth Leopold maneuver, is used to determine the degree of fetal descent and engagement.

 

Option B. Abdominal grip: This term is not specific to any of the Leopold maneuvers and is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the first Leopold maneuver, used to determine the fetal part located in the fundus of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pawlik grip (third Leopold maneuver) involves grasping the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis to assess the engagement of the presenting part of the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 89-90, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: HRT to induce puberty

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, no breast development and Prader 3 genitalia was found to have raised FSH. Her karyotype revealed 45 X0/46 XY and an ultrasound revealed Mullerian structures with poorly visualized gonads. What would be the next line of management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral gonadectomy

 

  • This patient has gonadal dysgenesis with virilization (Prader 3 classification is used to describe the degree of virilization of external genitalia)

 

 

  • If a Y-chromosome is identified during evaluation of primary amenorrhoea, laparoscopic prophylactic gonadectomy is recommended at the time of diagnosis to eliminate the risk of malignancy as dysgenetic gonads have a very high risk of malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. HRT to induce puberty: After gonadectomy, then HRT can be given for secondary sexual development

 

Option D. Clitoroplasty and Option A. vaginoplasty and other surgeries to correct the virilization may be required but the immediate next step would be to do gonadectomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whenever there is 46XY with primary amenorrhoea, always gonadectomy needs to be done in view of high risk of malignancy in dysgenetic gonads

 

Ref: Speroff’s Textbook of Reproductive Medicine

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to her to relieve the pain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Explanation:

 

To relieve leg cramps, the recommended technique is to:

 

  • Extend the knee: Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp.
  • Dorsiflex the foot: This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.

 

Leg cramps during pregnancy are commonly caused by factors such as deficiencies in serum calcium, elevated serum phosphorus, or increased pressure on the leg veins. Stretching and adjusting the foot position can provide immediate relief from cramps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Flexing the knee while dorsiflexing the foot can help in some cases, but extending the knee is generally more effective in relieving cramp pain.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Plantar flexion (pointing the toes downward) can actually exacerbate calf cramps. Extending the knee while performing plantar flexion is not as effective for cramp relief.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Flexing the knee while performing plantar flexion will likely increase the cramp discomfort. This position may not provide effective relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To relieve leg cramps during pregnancy, extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot.

 

Ref: https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy

questions.text: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18,31,33,45,52,58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/news/item/20-12-2022-WHO-updates-recommendations-on-HPV-vaccination-schedule

questions.text: Identify the grip shown in the image below: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral grip

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold manoeuvres)

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip /Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

The Lateral grip, also known as the Umbilical grip or Second Leopold's maneuver, is used to assess the position of the fetus in the uterus by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen. This grip helps determine the location of the fetal back and limbs.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Pawlik's grip: Also known as the First pelvic grip or Third Leopold's maneuver, Pawlik's grip involves palpating the lower uterine segment to determine the fetal presenting part (e.g., whether it is a head or breech presentation).

 

Option C. Pelvic grip: This term is sometimes used to refer to the Second pelvic grip or Fourth Leopold's maneuver, which is used to assess the fetal engagement and the degree of descent in the pelvic cavity.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the First Leopold's maneuver, which involves palpating the upper part of the uterus (fundus) to identify the fetal presentation (e.g., head or breech) and the lie of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lateral grip (Second Leopold's maneuver) is used to assess the position of the fetal back and limbs by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery

 

Cornual block, also known as proximal tubal obstruction, can be effectively managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation, typically guided by hysteroscopy and laparoscopy. This method has about an 85% success rate in restoring tubal patency, making it the next logical step in management for a woman with a bilateral cornual block.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cornual Block: Proximal tubal obstructions often require intervention to restore patency.
  • Hysteroscopy and Laparoscopy: These procedures allow for precise catheterization and cannulation to open the blocked tubes, leading to a high success rate.
  • Success Rate: Approximately 85% success in restoring tubal patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuboplasty: While tuboplasty is an option for distal tubal occlusion, it is not the first-line treatment for cornual block.

 

Option C. Hydrotubation: This procedure involves flushing the tubes with fluid but is less effective for treating cornual block compared to hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery. Success rates are poor (15-30 %)

 

Option D. In-vitro fertilization: IVF is typically considered when surgical interventions fail or are not suitable, particularly in women over 35 or those with severe tubal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornual block in a young woman with primary infertility should be managed with hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation to restore tubal patency before considering more invasive options like IVF.

 

Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition
